  user-select: none; cursor: default;
}

/* Triple bar glyph */

  display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;
  width: 12px; height: 12px;
}
.proxy-pill .icon svg {
  display: block; width: 100%; height: 100%;
  fill: currentColor; stroke: none;
  transform: translateY(-0.5px);
}

/* Count styling */
.proxy-pill .count {
  font-weight: 700;
  font-feature-settings: "tnum";
}

/* Disabled (if needed) */
.proxy-pill[aria-disabled="true"] { opacity: .45; }

/* Optional hover for web demo */
.proxy-pill:hover { filter: brightness(.95); }

Ah! I found the issue. The SVG paths have `fill="none" stroke="currentColor"` which means they're using **stroke** (outline) instead of **fill** (solid). Our CSS is trying to set `fill:url(#proxi-gradient)` but the SVG is actually using stroke.

Let me fix this by updating the CSS to target the stroke instead:


---

Tool use: **search_replace**


</details>

---

Perfect! Now the glyph should show the Proxi blue gradient. The issue was that the SVG uses `stroke` (outline) instead of `fill` (solid), so I changed the CSS to:

- `fill:none` (no solid fill)
- `stroke:url(#proxi-gradient)` (gradient stroke)
- `stroke-width:2` (maintain the line thickness)
- `stroke-linecap:round` (rounded line ends)

Now you should see the triple-bar glyph in the Proxi blue gradient! This will help us confirm if the CSS changes are working properly.
